myths.name: Cú Chulainn
description: Cú Chulainn is an Irish warrior hero and demigod in the Ulster Cycle of Irish mythology, as well as in Scottish and Manx folklore.
He is believed to be an incarnation of the Irish god Lugh, who is also his father.
His mother is the mortal Deichtine, sister of king Conchobar mac Nessa.
He gained the name 'Cú Chulainn' after killing Culann's fierce guard dog in self-defense and offering to take its place until a replacement could be reared, becoming the 'Hound (cú) of Culann'.
He had a prophecy that 'His great deeds would give him everlasting fame but his life would be short'.
Defended Ulster single-handedly against the armies of queen Medb of Connacht in the Táin Bó Cúailnge ('Cattle Raid of Cooley').
Cú Chulainn dies in battle, binding himself to a standing stone to die on his feet.

myths.name: Children of Lír
description: The Children of Lír is a tragic tale from Irish mythology that revolves around the transformation of Lir's children into swans.
After the death of Lir's first wife, Aoibh, his second wife Aoife grows jealous and curses the children to live as swans for 900 years.
They retain the power of speech and sing beautiful songs, becoming legends among the people.
The curse can only be broken upon the marriage of Lairgenn and Deoch, leading to a heartbreaking conclusion when they regain human form.
The children ultimately perish after being baptized, showcasing themes of love, loss, and transformation.

myths.name: Oisín of Tír na nÓg
myths.translation: Ush sheen of Tear na Noag
description: Oisín, a human hero, falls in love with Niamh, a woman of the Otherworld, who takes him to Tír na nÓg, the land of eternal youth, on a magical horse.
They share a deep bond, but Oisín becomes homesick after what seems like three years.
Niamh warns him never to touch the ground upon his return to Ireland, but upon arriving, he discovers that 300 years have passed.
When he falls from the horse and touches the ground, he instantly ages and dies, illustrating the themes of love, time, and loss.
